de.susebox.java.util
Class AbstractTokenizer

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--de.susebox.java.util.AbstractTokenizer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Tokenizer
Direct Known Subclasses:
InputStreamTokenizer, PluginTokenizer
public abstract class AbstractTokenizer
extends java.lang.Object
implements Tokenizer

This is the core class for mainstream Tokenizers. It implements the Tokenizer interface in a straightforward approach without too specialised parse optimizations.

The class is abstract, so it cannot be used by itself. It defines one abstract method, read(char[], int, int). This method is equivalent to the complex read methods of the InputStream interface, which is most likely to be used for implementing our read method.

Beside the Tokenizer interface, the class AbstractTokenizer provides some basic features for cascading (nested) tokenizers. Conider the usual HTML pages found today in the WWW. Most of them are a mixture of regular HTML, cascading style sheets (CSS) and embedded JavaScript. These different languages use different syntaxes, so one needs varous tokenizers on the same input stream.

There are also several methods suitable for own implementations in derived classes (isWhitespace(char), isSeparator(char) and isSequenceCommentOrString(int)). Being a general approach to tokenizing, the AbstractTokenizer may be not the fastest solution for ones specific situation. By implementing the mentioned methods, one can improve the performance through exact knowledge of what whitespaces, separators, comment starts and other special sequences are.

Author:
Heiko Blau
See Also:
Tokenizer, InputStreamTokenizer

Constructor Detail

AbstractTokenizer

public AbstractTokenizer()
Default constructor that sets the tokenizer control flags as it would be approbriate for C/C++ and Java. Found token images are copied. No line nor column informations are provided. Nested comments are not allowed.
The tokenizer will use the Tokenizer.DEFAULT_WHITESPACES and Tokenizer.DEFAULT_SEPARATORS for whitespace and separator handling.

AbstractTokenizer

public AbstractTokenizer(int flags)
This constructor takes the control flags to be used. It is a shortcut to: 
   Tokenizer t = new MyTokenizer();

   t.setParseFlags(flags);
See the Tokenizer interface for the supported flags.
The tokenizer will use the Tokenizer.DEFAULT_WHITESPACES and Tokenizer.DEFAULT_SEPARATORS for whitespace and separator handling if no explicit calls to setWhitespaces(java.lang.String) and setSeparators(java.lang.String) are made.

Parameters:
flags - tokenizer control flags

AbstractTokenizer

public AbstractTokenizer(int flags,
                         java.lang.String whitespaces,
                         java.lang.String separators)
This constructor takes the control flags, whitespace and separator strings to be used. It is a shortcut to: 
   Tokenizer t = new MyTokenizer();

   t.setParseFlags(flags);
   t.setWhitespaces(ws);
   t.setSeparators(sep);

Parameters:
flags - tokenizer control flags
whitespaces - the whitespace set
separators - the set of separating characters
See Also:
setWhitespaces(java.lang.String), setSeparators(java.lang.String)
Method Detail

read

protected abstract int read(char[] cbuf,
                            int offset,
                            int maxChars)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
This is the abstract method to be implemented by derived classes. It is supposed to deliver data from some sort of input stream to the tokenizer. The simplest implementation would use InputStream.read().

Parameters:
cbuf - buffer to receive data
offset - position from where the data should be inserted in cbuf
maxChars - maximum number of characters to be read into cbuf
Returns:
actually read characters or -1 on an end-of-file condition
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - anything that could happen during read, most likely IOException

reset

protected void reset()
This method should be called by derived classes whenever the input buffer has to be flushed. Such a situation may arise when the input source of the read method is changed.
Position informations are reset to start. All data in the input buffer are lost. So are the current token and any lookahead data. This is also true for instances there the Tokenizer.F_KEEP_DATA flag is set.

setParseFlags

public void setParseFlags(int flags)
Setting the control flags of the Tokenizer. Use a combination of the Tokenizer.F_... flags for the parameter.

Specified by:
setParseFlags in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
flags - the parser control flags

getParseFlags

public int getParseFlags()
Retrieving the parser control flags. A bitmask containing the F_... constants is returned.

Specified by:

Returns:
the current parser control flags

addString

public void addString(java.lang.String start,
                      java.lang.String end,
                      java.lang.String escape)
Registering a string description. Strings are things like the primitive string literals in C/C++, SQL varchar literals, but also the character literals of C/C++ and Java.
If the given string starting sequence is already known to the parser, it will simply be re-registered. Using this method on a known string with an associated companion will remove that companion.

Specified by:
addString in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
start - the starting sequence of a string
end - the finishing sequence of a string
escape - the escape sequence inside the string

addString

public void addString(java.lang.String start,
                      java.lang.String end,
                      java.lang.String escape,
                      java.lang.Object companion)
Registering a the sequences that are used for string-like text parts. This method supports also an information associated with the string, called the companion.
If the given string starting sequence is already known to the parser, it will simply be re-registered. Using this method on a known string with an associated companion will replace that companion against the given one.

Specified by:
addString in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
start - the starting sequence of a string
end - the finishing sequence of a string
escape - the escape sequence inside the string
companion - the associated information

addString

public void addString(java.lang.String start,
                      java.lang.String end,
                      java.lang.String escape,
                      java.lang.Object companion,
                      int flags)
Registering a the sequences that are used for string-like text parts. This method supports also an information associated with the string, called the companion.
If the given string starting sequence is already known to the parser, it will simply be re-registered. Using this method on a known string with an associated companion will replace that companion against the given one. This version of addString supports a bitmask of the F_... flags to modify the general tokenizer settings (see setParseFlags(int) for this special element.

Specified by:
addString in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
start - the starting sequence of a string
end - the finishing sequence of a string
escape - the escape sequence inside the string
companion - the associated information
flags - modification flags

getStringCompanion

public java.lang.Object getStringCompanion(java.lang.String start)
Retrieving the information associated with a certain string. Only the starting sequence is nessecary to identify the string. If the string is not known to the parser, null will be returned.
If one needs to know if a string exists without a companion or if the string is unknown so far, use also the method stringExists(java.lang.String).

Specified by:
getStringCompanion in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
start - the starting sequence of a string

getStrings

public java.util.Iterator getStrings()

Specified by:
getStrings in interface Tokenizer
Returns:

setWhitespaces

public void setWhitespaces(java.lang.String whitespaces)
Setting the whitespace character set of the tokenizer. It is possible to use ranges like "a-z" when more than two whitespace characters are neighbours in the UNICODE character set.
Whitespaces are sequences that have the same syntactical meaning as one single whitespace character would have. That means " " (many spaces) is the same as " " (one space).

Specified by:
setWhitespaces in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
whitespaces - the whitespace set

getWhitespaces

public java.lang.String getWhitespaces()
Obtaining the whitespace character set. The set may contain ranges.

Specified by:
getWhitespaces in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
the currently active whitespace set
See Also:
setWhitespaces(java.lang.String)

setSeparators

public void setSeparators(java.lang.String separators)
Setting the separator set. This set may contain ranges. A range is a character (lower limit) followed by a '-' (minus) followed by a second character (upper limit). A range of "a-z" means: all characters in the UNICODE character set between and including 'a' and 'z'. Ranges should be used whenever possible since they speed up the parsing process.
Separators are characters that are significant for the syntax. A sequence of separators is NOT equal to one single separator. Thats the difference to whitespaces.

Specified by:
setSeparators in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
separators - the set of separating characters

getSeparators

public java.lang.String getSeparators()
Obtaining the separator set of the Tokenizer. The set may contain ranges.

Specified by:
getSeparators in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
the currently used set of separating characters
See Also:
setSeparators(java.lang.String)

addLineComment

public void addLineComment(java.lang.String lineComment)
Registering a the starting sequence of a line comment. The line comment is a special type of whitespace. It starts with the given character sequence and contains all characters up to and including the next end-of-line character(s).
Although most languages have only one line comment sequence, it is possible to use more than one.
If the given line comment starting sequence is already known to the parser, it will simply be re-registered. Using this method on a known line comment with an associated companion will effectively remove the companion.

Specified by:
addLineComment in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
lineComment - the starting sequence of the line comment

addLineComment

public void addLineComment(java.lang.String lineComment,
                           java.lang.Object companion)
Registering a the starting sequence of a line comment. The line comment is a special type of whitespace. It starts with the given character sequence and contains all characters up to and including the next end-of-line character(s).
Although most languages have only one line comment sequence, it is possible to use more than one.
This method supports also an information associated with the line comment, called the companion.
If the given line comment starting sequence is already known to the parser, it will simply be re-registered. Using this method on a known line comment with an associated companion will replace that companion against the given one.

Specified by:
addLineComment in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
lineComment - the starting sequence of a line comment
companion - the associated information

                           int flags)

Although most languages have only one line comment sequence, it is possible to use more than one.
This method supports also an information associated with the line comment, called the companion.
If the given line comment starting sequence is already known to the parser, it will simply be re-registered. Using this method on a known line comment with an associated companion will replace that companion against the given one.
This version of addLineComment supports a bitmask of the F_... flags to modify the general tokenizer settings (see setParseFlags(int)) for this special element.

Specified by:

getLineCommentCompanion

public java.lang.Object getLineCommentCompanion(java.lang.String lineComment)
Retrieving the associated object of a certain line comment. If the given starting sequence of a line comment is not known to the parser, then the method returns null.
To distinguish between an unknown line comment and companion-less line comment, use the method lineCommentExists(java.lang.String).

addBlockComment

public void addBlockComment(java.lang.String start,
                            java.lang.String end)
Registering a block comment with the parser. This version takes only the starting and finishing sequence of the block comment.
If the given starting sequence is already known to the parser, the block comment is simply re-registered. Using this method on a known block comment with an associated companion will remove that companion.

Specified by:
addBlockComment in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
start - the starting sequence of the block comment
end - the finishing sequence of the block comment

                            java.lang.String end,
                            java.lang.Object companion)
Registering a block comment with the parser. Beside the obviously nessecary starting and finishing sequence of the block comment, it takes an object that is associated with the block comment, called the companion.
If the given starting sequence is already known to the parser, the block comment is simply re-registered. Using this method on a known block comment with an associated companion will replace that companion against the given one.

Specified by:
addBlockComment in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:

end - the finishing sequence of the block comment
companion - information object associated with this block comment

If the given starting sequence is already known to the parser, the block comment is simply re-registered. Using this method on a known block comment with an associated companion will replace that companion against the given one.
This version of addBlockComment supports a bitmask of the F_... flags to modify the general tokenizer settings (see setParseFlags(int)) for this special element.

getCurrentLine

public int getCurrentLine()
Query the current row. The method can only be used if the flag F_COUNT_LINES has been set. Without this flag being set, the return value is undefined. Note that row counting starts with 0, while editors often use 1 for the first row.

Specified by:
getCurrentLine in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
current row (starting with 0) or -1 if the flag Tokenizer.F_COUNT_LINES is set

Retrieve the current column. The method can only be used if the flag F_COUNT_LINES has been set. Without this flag being set, the return value is undefined. Note that column counting starts with 0, while editors often use 1 for the first column in one row.

Specified by:
getCurrentColumn in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
current column number (starting with 0)

addSpecialSequence

public void addSpecialSequence(java.lang.String specSeq)
Registering a special sequence of characters. Such sequences may be multicharacter operators like the shift operators in Java. Unlike keywords, special sequences act also as separators between other tokens. If one special sequence is the prefix of other special sequences (in Java the shift operator >> is the prefix of the shift operator >>>), always the longest possible match is returned. Testing on special sequences takes place after whitespaces and comments are ruled out, but before ordinary separators are tested.

Specified by:
addSpecialSequence in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
specSeq - special sequence to register
See Also:
addKeyword(java.lang.String), setSeparators(java.lang.String)

addSpecialSequence

public void addSpecialSequence(java.lang.String specSeq,
                               java.lang.Object companion)
Registering a special sequence of characters. Such sequences may be multicharacter operators like the shift operators in Java. Unlike keywords, special sequences act also as separators between other tokens. If one special sequence is the prefix of other special sequences (in Java the shift operator >> is the prefix of the shift operator >>>), always the longest possible match is returned. Testing on special sequences takes place after whitespaces and comments are ruled out, but before ordinary separators are tested. This form of addSpecialSequence also takes an object associated with the special sequence, called the companion.

Specified by:
addSpecialSequence in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
specSeq - special sequence to register
companion - information object associated with this special sequence
See Also:
addKeyword(java.lang.String), setSeparators(java.lang.String)

hasMoreToken

public boolean hasMoreToken()
Checking if there are more tokens available. This method will return true until and enf-of-file condition is encountered during a call to nextToken() or next().
That means, that the EOF is returned one time, afterwards hasMoreToken will return false. Furthermore, that implies, that the method will return true at least once, even if the input data stream is empty.
The method can be conveniently used in a while loop.

Specified by:
hasMoreToken in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
true if a call to nextToken() or next() will succed, false otherwise

nextToken

public Token nextToken()
                throws TokenizerException
Retrieving the next Token. The method works in this order:
  1. Check for an end-of-file condition. If there is such a condition then return it.
  2. Try to collect a sequence of whitespaces. If such a sequence can be found return if the flag F_RETURN_WHITESPACES is set, or skip these whitespaces.
  3. Check the next characters against all known line and block comments. If a line or block comment starting sequence matches, return if the flag F_RETURN_WHITESPACES is set, or skip the comment. If comments are returned they include their starting and ending sequences (newline in the case of a line comment)
  4. Check the next characters against all known string starting sequences. If a string begin could be identified return the string until and including the closing sequence
  5. Check the next characters against all known special sequences. Especially, find the longest possible match. If a special sequence could be identified then return it.
  6. Check for ordinary separators. If one could be found return it.
  7. Check the next characters against all known keywords. If a keyword could be identified then return it.
  8. Return the text portion until the next whitespace, comment, special sequence or separator.

Specified by:
nextToken in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
found Token including the EOF token
Throws:
TokenizerException - generic exception (list) for all problems that may occur while parsing (IOExceptions for instance)

next

public java.lang.String next()
                      throws TokenizerException
This method is a convenience method. It returns only the next token image without any informations about its type or associated information.

Specified by:
next in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
the token image of the next token
Throws:
TokenizerException - generic exception (list) for all problems that may occur while parsing (IOExceptions for instance)

Specified by:
currentToken in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
the token that was found by the last call to nextToken or next

Specified by:
current in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
the token image of the current token
See Also:
currentToken()

getLineNumber

public int getLineNumber()
If the flag Tokenizer.F_COUNT_LINES is set, this method will return the line number starting with 0 in the input stream. Lines are terminated by one of the following end-of-line sequences:
  • Carriage Return (ASCII 13, '\r'). This EOL is used on Apple Macintosh
  • Linefeed (ASCII 10, '\n'). This is the UNIX EOL character.
  • Carriage Return + Linefeed ("\r\n"). This is used on MS Windows systems.
Note that we didn't choose to use the system property "line.separator" since today windows files are transfered to UNIX and Macs and vice versa. However, a combination of '\n' with a subsequent '\r' is considered to be two lines.

Specified by:
getLineNumber in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
the current line number starting with 0 or -1 if no line numbers are supplied.
See Also:
getColumnNumber()

getColumnNumber

public int getColumnNumber()
If the flag Tokenizer.F_COUNT_LINES is set, this method will return the current column positionstarting with 0 in the input stream.

Specified by:
getColumnNumber in interface Tokenizer
Returns:
the current column position
See Also:
getLineNumber()

             throws TokenizerException

The method returns the same value than an immediately following call to currentlyAvailable() would return.

skip

public void skip(int numberOfChars)
          throws java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
Deprecated.  

This method tells the tokenizer to skip the given number of characters starting on the current read position as can be retrieved by getReadPosition(). The given number of characters must be less or equal to currentlyAvailable() - (getReadPosition() - getRangeStart()).
The method is deprecated according to the deprecation in the Tokenizer interface.

Specified by:
skip in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
numberOfChars - Number of characters to skip
Throws:
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the parameter numberOfChars exceeds the number of characters ahead of the current read position

getTextUnchecked

public java.lang.String getTextUnchecked(int start,
                                         int len)
Retrieve text from the currently available range. The start and length parameters must be inside getRangeStart() and getRangeStart + currentlyAvailable().
In contrast to the getText(int, int) method this one does not check for correct parameters. Two situations may arise:
  • an IndexOutOfBoundsException may occure
  • uninitialized data may be retrieved

Parameters:
start - position where the text begins
len - length of the text
Returns:
the text beginning at the given position ith the given length

getChar

             throws java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
Get a single character from the current text range.

Specified by:
getChar in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
pos - position of the required character
Returns:
the character at the specified position
Throws:
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the parameter pos is not in the available text range (text window)

getCharUnchecked

public char getCharUnchecked(int pos)
This is a method designed to be used by those who can guarantee to be in a valid position range. It is equivalent to the getChar(int) method above except that it does not check for a invalid position.
When passing an invalid position value, two situations may occure: The invalid position is really out of bounds of the input buffer (an unchecked exception will be thrown) or it points into an area where old or even initial values lay.

Parameters:
pos - position of the required character
Returns:
the character at the specified position

setReadPositionAbsolute

public void setReadPositionAbsolute(int position)
                             throws java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
This method sets the tokenizers current read position to the given absolute read position. It realizes one type of rewind / forward operations. The given position must be inside the intervall getRangeStart() and getRangeStart() + currentlyAvailable() - 1.
The operation does not affect the return values of current() and currentToken().
When using this method with embedded tokenizers, the user is responsible to set the read position in the currently used tokenizer. It will be propagated by the next call to switchTo(de.susebox.java.util.AbstractTokenizer). Until that point, a call to this method has no effect on the other tokenizers sharing the same data source.

Specified by:
setReadPositionAbsolute in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
position - absolute position for the next parse operation
Throws:
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the parameter position is not in the available text range (text window)
See Also:
setReadPositionRelative(int)

setReadPositionRelative

public void setReadPositionRelative(int offset)
                             throws java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
This method sets the tokenizers new read position the given number of characters forward (positive value) or backward (negative value) starting from the current read position. It realizes one type of rewind / forward operations. The given offset must be greater or equal than getRangeStart() - getReadPosition() and lower than currentlyAvailable() - getReadPosition().
The operation does not affect the return values of current() and currentToken().
When using this method with embedded tokenizers, the user is responsible to set the read position in the currently used tokenizer. It will be propagated by the next call to switchTo(de.susebox.java.util.AbstractTokenizer). Until that point, a call to this method has no effect on the other tokenizers sharing the same data source.

Specified by:
setReadPositionRelative in interface Tokenizer
Parameters:
offset - number of characters to move forward (positive offset) or backward (negative offset)
Throws:
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the parameter offset would move the read position out of the available text range (text window)
See Also:
setReadPositionAbsolute(int)

addTokenizer

public void addTokenizer(AbstractTokenizer tokenizer)
Adding an embedded tokenizer. Embedded tokenizer work on the same input buffer as their base tokenizer. A situation where embedded tokenizer could be applied, is a HTML stream with cascading style sheet (CSS) and JavaScript parts.
There are no internal means of switching from one tokenizer to another. This should be done by the caller using the method switchTo(de.susebox.java.util.AbstractTokenizer).

Parameters:
tokenizer - an embedded tokenizer

switchTo

public void switchTo(AbstractTokenizer tokenizer)
              throws TokenizerException
Changing fron one tokenizer to another. If the given tokenizer has not been added with addTokenizer(de.susebox.java.util.AbstractTokenizer), an exception is thrown.
The switchTo method does the nessecary synchronisation between this and the given tokenizer. The user is therefore responsible to use switchTo whenever a tokenizer change is nessecary. It must be done this way: 
   Tokenizer base     = new MyTokenizer(...)
   Tokenizer embedded = new MyTokenizer(...)

   // setting properties (comments, keywords etc.)
   ...

   // embedding a tokenizer
   base.addTokenizer(embedded);
   
   // tokenizing with base
   ...
   if (switch_condition) {
     base.switchTo(embedded);
   }

   // tokenizing with embedded
   ...
   if (switch_condition) {
     embedded.switchTo(base);
   }
That way we avoid a more complex synchronisation between tokenizers whenever one of them parses the next data in the input stream. However, the danger of not synchronized tokenizers remains, so take care.

Parameters:
tokenizer - the tokenizer that should be used from now on
TokenizerException

isWhitespace

protected boolean isWhitespace(char testChar)
This method checks if the character is a whitespace. Implement Your own code for situations where this default implementation is not fast enough or otherwise not really good.

Parameters:
testChar - check this character
Returns:
true if the given character is a whitespace, false otherwise

readWhitespaces

protected int readWhitespaces(int startingAtPos,
                              int maxChars)
                       throws TokenizerException
This method detects the number of whitespace characters starting at the given position. It should use getChar(int) or getCharUnchecked(int) to retrieve a character to check.
The method should return the number of characters identified as whitespaces starting from and including the given start position.
Do not attempt to actually read more data or do anything that leads to the change of the data source or to tokenizer switching. This is done by the tokenizer framework.

Parameters:
startingAtPos - start checking for whitespace from this position
maxChars - if there is no non-whitespace character, read up to this number of characters
Returns:
number of whitespace characters starting from the given offset
Throws:
TokenizerException - failure while reading data from the input stream

readString

protected int readString(int startingAtPos,
                         int maxChars)
                  throws TokenizerException
This method reads characters in a string until it detects the end of the string (this is the end sequence of the string, '"' in C and Java) It should use getChar(int) or getCharUnchecked(int) to retrieve a character to check.
The method should return the number of characters identified as parts of the string starting from and including the given start position.
Do not attempt to actually read more data or do anything that leads to the change of the data source or to tokenizer switching. This is done by the tokenizer framework.

Parameters:
startingAtPos - start reading the string from this position
maxChars - check up to this number of characters
Returns:
number of characters being part of the line comment
Throws:
TokenizerException - something happened

isKeyword

protected TokenizerProperty isKeyword(int startingAtPos,
                                      int length)
This method checks if the character sequence starting at a given position with a given lenght is a keyword. If so, it returns the keyword description as TokenizerProperty object.
If the method needs to build a string from the character sequence it may use getText(int, int) or getTextUnchecked(int, int) to retrieve it.
This method is should be overwritten by derived classes having their own keyword handling.

Parameters:
startingAtPos - check at this position
length - the candidate has this number of characters
Returns:
TokenizerProperty describing the keyword or null

readMoreData

protected int readMoreData()
                    throws TokenizerException
This method organizes the input buffer. It moves the current text window if nessecary or allocates more space, if data should be kept completely (see the Tokenizer.F_KEEP_DATA flag). Its main purpose is to call the read(char[], int, int) method of the implementing class.

Returns:
number of read bytes or -1 if an end-of-file condition occured
Throws:
TokenizerException - wrapped exceptions from the read(char[], int, int) method

synchronizeAll

protected void synchronizeAll(int readPosOffset)
When the method readMoreData() changes the contents of the input buffer or the input buffer itself, all embedded tokenizers must be synchronized. That means their member variables are adjusted to the base tokenizer.

Parameters:
readPosOffset - add this (negative) offset to all current read positions

offset - check at this position relative to the current read position
Returns:
true if a separator was found at the given offset, false otherwise
Throws:
TokenizerException - failure while reading data from the input stream

test4SpecialSequence

protected boolean test4SpecialSequence(Token token)
                                throws TokenizerException
Check if the current read position is the start of a special sequence. If so retrieve the special sequence.

Parameters:
token - add information about the special sequence to this buffer
Returns:
true if a special sequence was found, false otherwise
Throws:
TokenizerException - failure while reading data from the input stream

completeSpecialSequence

protected void completeSpecialSequence(Token token)
                                throws TokenizerException
After having identified a special sequence, this method completes this sequence and stores information about it in the given Token. Note that a special sequence is not identical to the token image that comprises the special sequence. For instance, a line comment start with the character sequence that identifies the line comment but contains also the data up to and including the end-of-line combination.

Parameters:
token - add information about the separator to this buffer
TokenizerException

isSpecialSequence

protected boolean isSpecialSequence(int offset)
                             throws TokenizerException
This method checks at the given offset if it contains a a special sequence. Unlike the method test4SpecialSequence(de.susebox.java.util.Token) it does nothing more.

Parameters:
offset - check at this position relative to the current read position
Returns:
true if a special sequence was found at the given offset, false otherwise
Throws:
TokenizerException - failure while reading data from the input stream

completeLineComment

protected int completeLineComment(int offset)
                           throws TokenizerException
Completing a line comment. After a line comment sequence has been found, all characters up to and including the end-of-line combination belong to the line comment. Note that on reaching end-of-file a line comment does not nessecarily ends with an end-of-line sequence (linefeed for example).

Parameters:
offset - start completing at this position relative to the current read position
Returns:
length of the line comment including start and terminating newline
Throws:
TokenizerException - failure while reading data from the input stream

completeBlockComment

protected int completeBlockComment(int offset,
                                   TokenizerProperty prop)
                            throws TokenizerException
Completing a block comment. After a block comment sequence has been found, all characters up to and including the end sequence of the block comment belong to the block comment. Note that on reaching end-of-file a block comment does not nessecarily ends with an end-of-block-comment sequence.

Parameters:
offset - start completing at this position relative to the current read position
Returns:
length of the block comment including start and end sequence
Throws:
TokenizerException - failure while reading data from the input stream

completeString

protected int completeString(int offset,
                             TokenizerProperty prop)
                      throws TokenizerException
Completing a string. After a string start sequence has been found, all characters up to and including the end-of-string sequence belong to the string. Note that on reaching end-of-file a string does not nessecarily ends with an end-of-string sequence.

Parameters:
offset - start completing at this position relative to the current read position
Returns:
length of the string including start and end sequence
Throws:
TokenizerException - failure while reading data from the input stream

comparePrefix

protected int comparePrefix(int offset,
                            java.lang.String prefix,
                            boolean noCase)
                     throws TokenizerException
This method compares the characters at the given offset (from the current read position) with the given prefix.

Parameters:
offset - start comparing at this offset from the current read position
noCase - case- or not case-sensitive comparison
Returns:
0 if the the given prefix matches the input stream, -1 on EOF and 1 if not matching
Throws:
TokenizerException - failure while reading data from the input stream

indexInSet

protected int indexInSet(char ch,
                         java.lang.String set)
A given character is searched in the given character set. This set may contain ranges, for example "a-z" for all lowercase alpha characters. To use the minus sign itself, escape it by "\-".

Returns:
index in the given character set where the given character was found or -1 when not ound

adjustLineAndColumn

protected void adjustLineAndColumn(int type,
                                   int length)
The method recomputes the line and column position of the tokenizer, if the flag Tokenizer.F_COUNT_LINES is set. It gets the token type of the Token that has been retrieved by the calling nextToken(). Using the tokenizer control flags and certain other information it tries to to find end-of-line sequences as fast as possible. For example, a line comment should always contain a end-of-line sequence, so we can simply increase the line count and set the column count to 0.

Parameters:
type - the type of the current token
length - the length of the current token
